stance_1: Flavor and texture of meat are enjoyable
justification: Enjoying the flavor and texture of meat supports the habit of eating meat.
The interviewee explicitly states that they grew up eating meat and continue to do so.

stance_2: Meat has a lot of protein
justification: The nutritional value of meat (protein) is mentioned as a positive aspect, supporting the behavior of eating meat.

stance_2: My social contacts eat similar amounts of meat
justification: The interviewee states both they and their social contacts eat similar amounts of meat, suggesting social reinforcement.

stance_1: Flavor and texture of meat are enjoyable
stance_2: My social contacts eat similar amounts of meat
justification: The interviewee explains that social contacts enjoy flavor and texture of meat, which supports similar meat-eating habits.

stance_2: I enjoy the versatility of meat
justification: Stating that meat is versatile for cooking supports eating meat.

stance_1: I enjoy the versatility of meat
stance_2: Meat has a lot of protein
justification: Enjoying meat's versatility and its protein content both reinforce its desirability.

stance_1: I have meatless meals to save money
stance_2: I try to find the best prices for meat
justification: Both behaviors are explicitly linked to saving money on groceries.

stance_2: I have meatless meals to save money
justification: Eating meat and intentionally having meatless meals to save money are behaviors in tension, as one reduces meat intake for financial reasons.

stance_1: I have meatless meals to save money
stance_2: I try to find the best prices for meat
justification: Both behaviors are explicitly motivated by a desire to save money on groceries.
